items.title: Oppression/Freedom: Let Me Out
items.subTitle: 2023 Scholastic Art Award Gold Key Winner/Applied Art Student Award Winner (Published in website + Magazine)
items.description: I view every school like a different box. Students are forced to be placed into these boxes so that schools can evaluate their success with various standards. For example, to put yourself into the “Ivy” box, you need a good SAT score, a high GPA, good activities, and maybe a wealthy or successful parent. Even if you have all that, you need some luck. However, most of the time, what’s written on the resume or application of an applicant isn’t who one really is. There are additional unwritten qualities in each person that makes them a separate and special individual. To me, education means more than just putting oneself into boxes. I’ve seen my friends choosing to take the hardest AP classes not because they actually are interested in the material, but rather because the classes will get them into the “good colleges.” I think education should not be disregarded as a simple process of making and fitting into boxes. Hopefully, I want to encourage students with this artwork, telling them that creativity should not have a limit or a standard to it. Unbox yourself! Be who you truly are! Take the classes you want to take, and that will make you who you want to be in the future.

items.title: Nourishment of Tree and of Man
items.subTitle: 2023 Applied Art Student Award Winner (Published on Website + Magazine)
items.description: As a history student and artist, I’ve always been interested in using historical references in my artwork. When I saw the prompt for the competition, I immediately thought of a famous line said by the famous politician GuanZhong stressing the importance of education in China: “十年树木，百年树人。” This translates to “It takes ten years to nurture a tree, but it takes 100 years to educate a man.” Nurturing a man is ten times harder, but it is fundamentally important for the prosperity of society. Interestingly enough, the Chinese character 树 here not only refers to the tree but also acts like a verb and action that can be interpreted as educating, establishing, or setting up. This really intrigued me to create an art piece on this topic. In the piece, I used actual tree branches, cloth, Barbie dolls, paper, rope, and paint. As I reaped the doll with cloth and wove it onto the tree, I drew a connection between the growth of a tree and the growth of a man. I hang little paper tags on the trees to illustrate what education is for me: Hope, Growth, Life, Wealth, and Status. I hope this artwork can prompt viewers to think about what education means for them.

items.title: U.S / US
items.subTitle: 2023 Applied Art Student Award Winner (Published in Magazine & Website) / 2023 Scholastic Art Award Honorable Mention
items.description: A little over a year ago I saw the Arc De Triomphe in Paris all wrapped and covered up. Christo, one of the greatest artists of the 21st century, died the year before, but his collaborators did this as one his last wishes. Christo never explained why he did it; rather he cared about the spectacle of public art. The art, of course, conveys meaning: perhaps about covering up France’s military history or maybe the exact opposite by celebrating the “gift” of France’s identity. But the key for Christo was that the viewer got to decide, as art for him was meant to be viewed, judged, and appreciated by the public. Christo has inspired my own art. I was born and grew up in Beijing. For the Chinese, the Great Wall is one of our proudest accomplishments, one of the greatest infrastructure projects ever, spanning over 13,000 miles. It was therefore a shock to realize in my research that the Great Wall might not have been so great. The wall was built over centuries through the death of hundreds of thousands of prisoners and peasants. This is why historians call it the “longest cemetery on earth.” Even worse, I realized we in China had walls all around us. There was no freedom of expression or freedom of the press. We have long been trapped by invisible walls. So when I came to the US, I at first felt free. But slowly, over time, I realized maybe there were different walls around race, ethnicity and identity. I felt it in subtle ways, such as the assumptions people made about me because of how I looked or the way I talked. I realized we all have walls, but maybe they exist in our minds more than in the real world. That is why I made a large public art exhibition at my school. It took me three months. The sculpture is made of heavy fabric, one side white and the other black, hung on metal rods ten feet high, that are secured into the ground. I stenciled a word on each side: Difference; Identity; Perspective; Equality. I cut the fabric into long strips so one could pass through it. The key was that I set it up while my entire school was in a meeting. They went into the building as usual, but when they came out, the walkways were “blocked” by my exhibition. At first, students walked around the exhibition. But soon people started to walk through, and realized the sides displayed different colors and words.

items.title: This Decade
items.subTitle: 2023 Summer Celebrating Art Award Winner (Published in Magazine)
items.description: The past decade has consisted of both great as well as painful moments. These events taught us different lessons: some are good, while some are bad. Remember the past and dream about the future!
items.material: Flower Bud、Cicada Shell、Cardboard、Acrylic paint、Bamboo Stick、Tree branch、Medical Gauze、Rice Paper、Ink、Glue.

items.title: Peace is Just a Word：Blood Stains
items.subTitle: 2023 Scholastic Art Award Silver Key Winner
items.description: I was inspired by what I’ve learned about the United Nation from my history teacher, while connecting it with the ongoing War between Russia and Ukraine. What exactly can the UN do if they have no power to prevent war from happening? “Peace, Dignity, and Equality”, the three words that have been used to describe the UN before seem a little ironic during this time.
items.material: Flower Bud、Cicada Shell、Cardboard、Acrylic paint、Spray paint、Bamboo Stick、Rice Paper、Glue.

items.title: The City of Art: Identity & Symbolism
items.description: When we are walking down the street, we often see street arts on a random wall. These murals seem to represent the culture of the city as well as the identity of the artists who created them. All kinds of symbols and murals were painted on the “boxes” that made the city look more lively than ever.

items.title: Identity Unboxed: Building the Freedom Towers
items.subTitle: 2023 Scholastic Art Award Winner Honorable Mention
items.description: I was born and raised in Beijing, an extremely busy, indifferent, and restricted city. Everyone is doing their own job in the different “boxes” that they were being put into. Do not yield to conformity and do not restrict yourself in these boxes; build a freedom tower and climb to the top so that you might be able to see a brighter sky.
items.material: Flower Bud、Cicada Shell、Cardboard、Acrylic paint、Spray paint、Bamboo Stick、Glue.

items.title: Yin-Yang:I am Not A Color
items.subTitle: 2023 Scholastic Art Award Honorable Mention
items.description: The word Yinyang in China symbolizes two forces: Yang(White) represents the Day, light, and strength; Yin(Black) represents the Night, darkness, and flexibility. It was widely accepted in ancient China that Yin and Yang complement each other and that’s how we and our world are born. However, in our modern world, White and Black seem to become two opposite and conflicting forces in many aspects of our life. This sculpture is my attempt to say that White and Black make each other perfect. We should embrace more possibilities instead of just having absolute right or wrong.
items.material: Flower Bud、Cicada Shell、Paper Tube、Acrylic paint、Rice Paper、Glue.

items.title: The Paper of Hope
items.description: Inspired by the white paper protest that happened in China, I created this art because I think the paper that people were holding in their hands during this protest was a paper that holds a huge weight because it represents: Hope.

items.title: If Humans Could Fly
items.subTitle: 2023 Scholastic Art Award Winner Honorable mention
items.description: I’ve always wondered, what would happen if humans became birds? I admire the freedom that Birds have because they can get to wherever they want. I wish I could be a bird.
items.material: Flower Bud、Cicada Shell、Paper Tube、Acrylic paint、Tree branch、Glue.
